DOCNAME: CASE OF CONSTANTIN TUDOR v. ROMANIA
CONCLUSION: Violation of Article 3 - Prohibition of torture (Article 3 - Degrading treatment) (Substantive aspect)
JUDGES: Alvina Gyulumyan;Corneliu Bîrsan;Ján Šikuta;Johannes Silvis;Josep Casadevall;Kristina Pardalos;Luis López Guerra;Nona Tsotsoria
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE . He is currently detained in LOC .
CARDINAL . By a final judgment of DATE ORG sentenced the applicant to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment for human trafficking .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was detained by ORG after being returned from GPE , where he had fled in DATE , and started serving his prison sentence .

CARDINAL . In his initial letter addressed to the ORG on DATE the applicant expressly stated that his rights guaranteed by LAW had been breached in so far as , inter alia , he had been quartered ( cazat ) in FAC , a penitentiary notorious as a place of torture and physical and mental terror because of inhuman and degrading detention conditions . He further contended that his assertions had already been proved before the ORG in the case of GPE v. GPE , no . CARDINAL , DATE , and that they were supported by successive reports of ORG for the Prevention of Torture ( ORG ) .

CARDINAL . In respect of the hygiene conditions , the ORG submitted that every year the prison administration signed contracts for rodent and pest control with specialised companies . Disinfection of the detention rooms was carried out at least once DATE . Moreover , the quality of the drinking water was examined regularly by the prison administration with the aid of a specialised laboratory . Furthermore , the applicant had been provided with a special food diet approved by the prison doctor , which was prepared and served in accordance with the required hygiene conditions . The food was fresh and of good quality .

CARDINAL . Since DATE significant rehabilitation work had been carried out by the prison authorities . The heating network , the sewerage and the water supply systems had been repaired . Some sections of the prison and detention rooms had also been modernised .
CARDINAL . On DATE and DATE the applicant was hospitalised in the psychiatric unit of ORG and was diagnosed with organic personality syndrome . He was prescribed treatment for his condition .
CARDINAL . On an unspecified date in DATE the applicant was diagnosed with spinal disc hernia . The examining doctor recommended that the applicant undergo surgery .

CARDINAL . DATE and DATE the applicant was subjected to several other medical examinations – both in prison and in civilian hospitals – that confirmed the above - mentioned diagnoses , and he was prescribed treatment with various medicines . The prison authorities provided him with the prescribed treatment for his organic personality syndrome and his spinal disc hernia .

CARDINAL . On DATE the doctor , M.M. , granted the applicant ’s request and indicated that he was scheduled for a nuclear magnetic resonance ( ORG ) scan at the PERSON private clinic .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was taken to the H. private clinic , where the ORG scan was carried out free of charge .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was re - examined by doctor PERSON in respect of his spinal disc hernia . He was recommended treatment for DATE and his surgery was scheduled for DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was taken to ORG for a neurosurgical examination . However , the neurosurgeon was absent and his examination had to be re - scheduled for DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was examined by doctor PERSON , a specialist neurologist working for ORG . According to her report , the applicant was suffering from lumbar pain . She prescribed treatment and recommended an urgent neurosurgical examination in respect of his condition .

CARDINAL . DATE and DATE the applicant ’s medical condition was regularly examined in both prison and private hospitals . On DATE and DATE the medical reports produced in respect of his conditions recorded that the applicant ’s general state of health was good .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Mina Minovici Forensic ORG produced a forensic report in respect of the applicant ’s medical condition . It concluded that after the spinal disc hernia the applicant needed physiotherapy for his recovery , which could be provided in prison hospitals .

CARDINAL . DATE and DATE the applicant ’s medical conditions were monitored regularly by prison hospitals . According to the medical records drawn up on DATE by the ORG doctor , his general medical condition was good .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant refused to be hospitalised in ORG and he requested to be taken to civilian hospitals for his post - surgical recovery treatment .

CARDINAL . In a letter of CARDINAL DATE ORG authorities informed the Government that the applicant had been provided free of charge with the medical treatment prescribed by doctors for the entire time he was detained in that prison .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged a complaint with the judge responsible for the execution of prison sentences in respect of the conditions of detention in PERSON and a lack of adequate medical care . The applicant also claimed compensation . He complained of inhuman and degrading treatment because : ( i ) the prison cells were infested with vermin ; ( ii ) the quality of the food and drinking water was poor ; ( iii ) proper facilities for personal and food hygiene were lacking ; and ( iv ) the cells lacked furniture and the general living conditions of the detainees were poor . On DATE , at the hearing before the judge responsible for the execution of prison sentences , the applicant stated that his complaint concerned a lack of medical care for his spinal disc hernia and insufficient medical treatment for his organic personality syndrome .

CARDINAL . By a decision of DATE the judge responsible for the execution of sentences dismissed the applicant ’s complaint . The judge held that FAC authorities had taken the necessary steps to combat the vermin infestation of the cells as they had signed pest control contracts with a number of companies and the cells were disinfected at least once DATE . Moreover , the judge held that the applicant ’s complaints concerning the poor quality of the food and drinking water and the lack of food and personal hygiene facilities were unfounded , as : ( i ) the food at the prison was prepared and stored on the basis of guidelines set by ORG ; ( ii ) the quality of the drinking water had been found to comply with legal requirements according to an expert report of the ORG water testing laboratory ; ( iii ) the applicant had access to the prison facilities necessary to ensure his personal hygiene ; and ( iv ) he was under an obligation to clean and air his room in accordance with the DATE schedule for detainees . The judge also held that there was no evidence that the general living conditions for detainees as provided for in PERSON No . CARDINAL/CARDINAL had not been met in the applicant ’s case . Finally , the judge held that the applicant was being provided with adequate medical care . He was kept under medical surveillance , was prescribed the medical treatment that the doctors considered appropriate for his medical condition and , in addition , his request to be treated at DATE ’s natural private clinic at his own expense had been examined according to the relevant legal provisions . The judge also rejected the applicant ’s claim for compensation , finding that the applicant could not bring a claim for compensation on the basis of the procedure provided for by Law No . CARDINAL/CARDINAL and that he therefore had to bring separate proceedings seeking compensation . The applicant appealed against the judge ’s decision .

CARDINAL . On an unspecified date in DATE the applicant brought proceedings in the ORG seeking temporary release from prison on medical grounds . The domestic court ordered an expert forensic report in respect of the applicant ’s medical condition .

CARDINAL . According to the expert forensic report produced by ORG on DATE , the applicant was suffering from , inter alia , a spinal disc hernia which required surgery and specialised post - surgery recovery . Consequently , the forensic expert report recommended the discontinuance of the applicant ’s prison sentence for DATE on the ground that the applicant ’s spinal disc hernia could not be operated on in a prison hospital .
CARDINAL . By a final judgment of DATE ORG allowed the applicant ’s action seeking his temporary release from prison on medical grounds and ordered his immediate release .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG authorities informed ORG that the applicant could not be released as ORG had issued a separate arrest warrant in his name on DATE in a separate set of proceedings concerning human trafficking .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG informed ORG authorities that the applicant ’s pre - trial detention on the basis of the arrest warrant of CARDINAL DATE had been extended by an interlocutory judgment of DATE . It does not appear from the evidence in the file that the applicant appealed against the interlocutory judgment of DATE .

CARDINAL . By a final judgment of DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s appeal against the decision of the judge responsible for the execution of sentences dated DATE , upholding the decision and finding that there was no evidence that the applicant ’s rights as a detainee had been breached .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was subjected to a psychiatric evaluation in ORG . The medical report confirmed that the applicant ’s organic personality syndrome had improved .

CARDINAL . By final interlocutory judgments of CARDINAL DATE , CARDINAL May , DATE , CARDINAL DATE , DATE , DATE and DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s actions seeking the discontinuance of the pre - trial detention ordered against him on DATE . Neither of the parties has provided the ORG with the reasoning part of the interlocutory judgments delivered by ORG .

DATE . On DATE ORG informed ORG authorities that following its interlocutory judgment delivered on DATE , the applicant ’s pre - trial detention ordered on the basis of the arrest warrant issued on DATE had been revoked and the applicant had been placed under an obligation not to leave town .
